Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character of the story. He is a miserly and ill-tempered businessman who is against the holiday Christmas. Scrooge was Marley's business partner and sole executor. He is a stingy and unfeeling employer who barks precise instructions to Cratchit and then leaves for the day. He is visited by three spirits on Christmas Eve, including the ghost of his former business partner, Jacob Marley.  Scrooge is a greedy and miserly old man who is visited by three spirits on Christmas Eve.
Jacob Marley was Ebenezer Scrooge's former business partner. He died seven years prior to the events of the story. Marley's ghost visits Scrooge on Christmas Eve.
Tim is Bob Cratchit's crippled son
'Change is a place where Scrooge rings money and is known to be good at it
Hamlet's father died before the play started

Scrooge and Marley were business partners for many years. Marley died seven years ago and Scrooge became the sole executor of Marley's will.  Some people who were new to the business mistakenly referred to Scrooge as "Marley".
Christmas Eve is the day before Christmas. In the story, the Three Spirits visit Scrooge on Christmas Eve.
The location where Scrooge lives
Scrooge's nephew is Scrooge's relative who celebrates Christmas. He visits Scrooge on Christmas Eve and invites him to dinner. Scrooge's nephew is in favor of celebrating the holiday Christmas.

Christmas is an annual holiday that Scrooge dreads.  It is a Christian holiday that Scrooge does not enjoy.  Scrooge's nephew wants to celebrate Christmas, but Scrooge has different views on the holiday.
Scrooge hates the holiday Christmas and believes there is no reason to celebrate it
Scrooge's nephew loves Christmas and wants his uncle to celebrate with him
Scrooge's nephew enjoys Christmas, while Scrooge does not. Despite Scrooge's aversion to the holiday, his nephew celebrates Christmas with enthusiasm.
Scrooge is Scrooge's nephew's uncle, and they do not see eye-to-eye on Christmas
The clerk is an employee of Scrooge who greets Scrooge's nephew warmly. When the nephew praises Christmas, the clerk cheers and is reprimanded by Scrooge for it.
A legislative branch of government that Scrooge's nephew is suggested to join
Scrooge's nephew is related to Scrooge as his uncle
Scrooge and his nephew disagree about how Christmas is celebrated
